docs.lead_paragraph: SHE ''wanted better,'' Audrey Buckmire says in explaining why taking care of other people's children from morning till evening provided an unfulfilling present and what she viewed as an unpromising future. Besides, she says, it left her virtually no time for her own little girl.

headline.main: For Women in Need, a Way to Something Better

docs.snippet: The Grace Institute, a nonprofit, 108-year-old school in Manhattan, provides tuition-free training in skilled office work to low-income women who are unemployed or have poorly paying or dead-end jobs.

docs.lead_paragraph: Enrollment in the Hewlett-Woodmere schools has declined nearly 10 percent since 2001, one of the steepest drops in Nassau County, according to district figures reported to the state. But every year, the district's tax levy has increased. In the 2001-2002 school year, the district raised $50 million from property taxes. For 2005-2006, with projected enrollment down by more than 300 students since 2001, the board of education proposed raising $72 million, a 60 percent jump in the levy per pupil over just four years. For the first time since 1995, voters in the district rejected the school budget on May 17. District officials, who say the services they are required to provide to a growing number of students in private schools are to blame for much of the increase, say they will put a smaller revised budget to voters on June 21.

headline.main: Going to the Well: The Rapid Rise in School Taxes

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: It's true that the power of genome decoding to predict illness can undermine any justification for a health insurance system that seeks profit by pooling patients who are least prone to disease. Simply ending this cherry-picking, however, begs the question of whether it would be wise to eliminate the profit motive, and with it the competition that has spurred progress in medicine. This question is more pertinent because the information technology that will make it possible to predict individual health prospects from a drop of blood also allows the analysis and comparison of the health care quality given by different providers.
